results.title: To help them learn (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Examines the role of audiovisual media in modern education. Encourages the use of media for captivating children’s attention, offering a variety of approaches to learning, and stimulating students through meaningful experiences.

results.title: To hell and back. Dr. Bavandra interview.
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
This video contains two programs from the Four Corners series. 1. To hell and back - schizophrenics talk about what it means to be a schizophrenic attempting to live in society. Treatment with drugs is discussed and the need for support from others is stressed. 2. Dr. Bavandra interview - Dr. Timotei Bavandra is interviewed about the coup in Fiji.
results.title_for_label: To hell and back. Dr. Bavandra interview.

results.title: To hear or not to hear
results.creator_credit: Jill Mansfield, Jeff Osment and Green Hill Films
results.brief_description: A domestic scene is enacted twice - once from the perspective of a busy woman preparing a meal and then as seen by her partially deaf husband. Gives insights into the frustrations of both.

results.title: To have and have not
results.creator_credit: Howard Hawks, Jack L. Warner and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Lauren Bacall’s sizzling screen debut in “To have and have not” also marked her first role opposite Humphrey Bogart. The film that brought this legendary couple together is an adaptation of the Ernest Hemingway novel, set on the German controlled island of Martinique during World War II. The compelling script by Jules Furthman and William Faulkner captures the drama of the war-torn 40’s and is peppered with witticisms and wisecracks. Supporting players Walter Brennan and Hoagy Carmichael keep the action brisk, but the scenes between sullen Bogie and silky Bacall exude a heat and humour that pervade the entire picture.

results.title: To forget Venice = Dimenticare Venezia
results.creator_credit: Franco Busati, Vivien Boder, Ennio DiMeo, Action Films and Rizzoli Film
results.brief_description: An old country house in Venice is inhabited by four women: Aunt Martha (Eleonora Giorgi), a widowed one-time opera singer; Anna, her adopted niece (Mariangela Melato); Claudia, a school teacher and Caterina, an elderly servant. One weekend they receive a visit from Nicky (Erland Josephson), Aunt Martha’s brother who lived there as a child, and his friend Picchio. A collision of characters takes place with frailty, immaturity and rejection all surfacing at once. The death of Aunt Martha provides the catalyst for each individual to re-evaluate themselves and consequently provide the incentive to forget the past and start a new life. In Italian with English sub-titles.

results.title: To everything there is a season
results.creator_credit: Brian Bosisto, South Australian Film Corporation and Bosisto Productions
results.brief_description: A general interest film exposing one of South Australia’s wildlife sanctuaries located at the Coorong. It instructively illustrates the interaction between the birds and the landscape against a backdrop of seasonal change. Of particular interest to students of the life sciences, conservationists and bird-watching societies. Narrated by John and Judith Dick.

results.title: To each a rightful share
results.creator_credit: Donald Fraser, Nicholas Balla and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Earth and mankind”.
This, to the privileged, is a fine-sounding principle; but to the underprivileged it is a call to action. Riots in Africa, India’s violence, China’s new dynamism, Japan’s intense industrialization - all these are seen as part of a great movement. Good historical overview of the rise of industrialization, with particular emphasis on the social affects (the growth in wealth brought on by industrialization).

results.title: To die for = Heaven's a drag
results.creator_credit: Peter Mackenzie Litten, Gary Fitzpatrick, British Screen, London Lighthouse and TDF Productions
results.brief_description: This comedy/drama about the impact of AIDS on a gay relationship draws on the same ‘ghostly lover’ premise as “Ghost” and “Truly, madly, deeply”. Mark, a drag performer, is HIV positive and in poor health. While he spends his last days at home preparing his own AIDS memorial quilt, his spunky young HIV negative boyfriend Simon, in denial about Mark’s impending death, cruises clubs and sleeps with other men. When Mark finally dies, Simon continues to pursue his hedonistic lifestyle until Mark returns to haunt his faithless lover. Mark’s endless beyond-the-grave pranks finally force Simon to face some long-submerged feelings and come to terms with his love and grief. While the patchy script undermines the film’s attempts to bring a comic touch to a serious subject, “To die for” offers a refreshing alternative to other films that focus solely on the horrors of the AIDS virus. Cast includes Thomas Arklie, Ian Williams, Tony Slattery, Dillie Keane.
